newsitem.title: CHINA: Cotton black market reappears in China - newspaper.
newsitem.headline: Cotton black market reappears in China - newspaper.

text.p: A black market in cotton has reappeared in some cotton-growing regions of China due to an improved market for cotton textiles and rising prices, the official Economic Reference News said on Wednesday.

It said the authorities should stamp out black market activities to stop a degradation of the quality of cotton on the market and to preserve the government tax income from sales through approved channels.

The newspaper said traders in the central province of Henan were offering to buy cotton from producers for more than the state purchase price, and were selling on to smaller factories that had difficulty getting cotton purchase quota.
It said many state-run cotton companies also had large stockpiles of cotton and had stopped buying new supplies, thereby offering an opportunity for black marketeers.
"Cotton is a special commodity which impacts on the national economy and the people's livlihood, and cotton textiles is a foreign exchange-earning pillar industry," the newspaper said.

"With the system for the market circulation of this commodity still incomplete, the government policy of not relaxing controls on sales, marketing and pricing is good for the state, for enterprises and for cotton farmers," it added.
